fields.comment: really a great step towards it application
google docs -> new drawing -> send link to other guy = easier collaboration, lots of builtin drawing tools and shapes, ability to save ur sessions

Our aim is to provide a more convenient way for the people to interact with less clicks and key-presses involved. 
User won't like to first open the link which we provide in a browser, then store the links for future use. We are unable to provide any sort of storage, we are just working on pidgin clients. Its totally google's wish of how to use there drawing application, if they provide us the api to use it we can deploy them in the client with some other way. 
What we are doing is based on the xmpp protocol hence the chat and whitebording will be simultaneous and nothing goes out of the protocol thread.

@Anonymous

 1. Session Management - Right now, we can't do that, you will need to save the white board status at some place. We don't own any server. Just contributing to a opensource for betterment of service but will try for this feature.
 2. Built in Drawing Tools and shapes - I am working on that. In the final release you can draw primitive shapes simply by dragging mouse or just by specifying coordinates etc.
 3. Why whiteboard over Google Drawing - We are concerned with Pidgin Users. Many times IM's are preferred over Emails. People will not links to share links all the time. If someday, Google will release their API for Drawing, then we will write a Pidgin Plugin for that.

Okay, my comment might be an overdose but what Anonymous says is correct too. The point is that I don't have the will to open a new /firefox/chrome/ tab, log into a google session, and I hardly want to save my sessions.

All that I want to do is to poke my friend while I chat :D. And the workflow with google docs just isin't right. They provide all the functionality BUT it's good enough if I can make small stuff while I chat on my favorite chat client ;)

used .wsgi method, however, have had to solve issue with WSGIDaemonProcess

my apache config part looks like:

    SetEnvIf HOST ^(?:www\.)?(.+)\.+?devinstance.com
    DJANGO_SETTINGS_MODULE=project.development_$1                                                                                                
                                                                                                                                                                                                               
........                                                                                                                                                                                                       

    WSGIDaemonProcess %{ENV:DJANGO_SETTINGS_MODULE} user=anatoly group=anatoly threads=25.
    WSGIScriptAlias / /home/anatoly/projects/git/wefollowipad/bin/wsgi

while in wsgi script i have

    def application(environ, start_response):
        os.environ['DJANGO_SETTINGS_MODULE'] = environ['DJANGO_SETTINGS_MODULE']
        if environ['wsgi.url_scheme'] == 'https':
            environ['HTTPS'] = 'on'
        return _application(environ, start_response)

Hi, 
Thanks for your reply.  

I just read [this](http://code.google.com/p/modwsgi/wiki/ConfigurationDirectives#WSGIDaemonProcess) from the mod wsgi wiki. From the scripts I figure that `WSGIDaemonProcess` sets the number of maximum separate threads the wsgi script for a particular domain. So any request for a particular domain will start a thread and all the subsequent requests dealt by that? I mean there is one thread per domain or some other way?

well, i realized that i need to read more about wsgi internals :)
but for sure WSGIDaemonProcess defers process name, not thread, and there is thread count setting for number of threads
Nice study Rohan. :) Many would find this useful

- Portability is a major issue !!
- Plus where is the cost of LCD screen ??? :P
- Also, considering upgrading the Graphics Card as well.

All in all, the config. looks good.

The monitor cost is included, in the end (around Rs. 8000).   

The portability doesn't seems that much affecting. If one only moves around the cabinate, then it is pretty feasible. The laptop anyways takes up much space.  

I am currently unsure of the graphics card. Only after the reviews of Z68 motherboard would help me decide the other stuff of the comp. I am thinking of even not getting one just now (Provided that the Z68 mobo is promising and affordable - mobo cost < P67 + Gfx card) and use the integrated HD graphics provided with the processor itself. It is sufficient for general graphics use.
